explanation: The report is correct. The calls to memcmp(userhash, entry->..., sizeof(...)) will read sizeof(...) bytes starting at the address given by the caller in userhash. The function only verifies that userhash_size matches the expected hash length, but it never checks that the caller-supplied pointer is non-NULL or that it actually refers to an object at least userhash_size bytes long. If a caller passes NULL or a pointer to a smaller buffer while claiming the correct size, memcmp will access out-of-bounds memory and thus violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. (MISRA requires that uses of these string/memory functions must not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.)
